{{merge|Healthcare in Sweden|date=July 2018}} The '''Swedish healthcare''' system is highly decentralized, and is universal for all citizens.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.keepeek.com/Digital-Asset-Management/oecd/economics/getting-better-value-for-money-from-sweden-s-healthcare-system_082725005676#.WiiR07pFxPY |title=Getting Better Value for Money from Sweden's Healthcare System {{!}} OECD READ edition|website=OECD iLibrary |access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref> The Swedish healthcare system is mainly financed through the public sector, and city councils run public healthcare. A total of 21 councils are in charge with primary and hospital care within the country. Private healthcare is rarity in Sweden, and even those private institutions work under the mandated city councils.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.keepeek.com/Digital-Asset-Management/oecd/economics/oecd-economic-surveys-sweden-2005/improving-quality-and-value-for-money-in-healthcare_eco_surveys-swe-2005-7-en#.WiiXqLpFxPY#page5|title=Improving Quality and Value for Money in Healthcare {{!}} OECD READ edition|website=OECD iLibrary|language=en|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref>The city councils regulates the rules and the establishment of potential private practices. Although in most countries care for the elderly or those who need psychiatric help is conducted privately, in Sweden local, publicly funded authorities are in charge of this type of care. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2015/apr/28/swedish-council-limit-private-profit-healthcare-public|title=Swedish council becomes first to limit private profits in healthcare|last=Orange|first=Richard|date=2015-04-28|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The Swedish government makes an effort to limit private firms in healthcare. The government takes the precautions to eliminate profit seeking in the welfare/public health sector.
== Inefficiencies == The Swedish health system is mainly effective but there are some problems within the system. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.keepeek.com/Digital-Asset-Management/oecd/economics/oecd-economic-surveys-sweden-2005_eco_surveys-swe-2005-en#.WiifnrpFxPY#page19|title=OECD Economic Surveys: Sweden 2005 {{!}} OECD READ edition|website=OECD iLibrary|language=en|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref> Increased access to primary care is one issue that arises. Most citizens in Sweden go to the hospital for routine check ups. Primary care needs to be made more readily accessible to Swedes instead of them going to hospitals for minor health needs. Another issue is Swedish emergency units are below the minimum safe size. The decentralized healthcare system in Sweden leads to this inefficiency, because of decentralization the counties are granted extreme amount of flexibility. The coordination between counties and municipalities is affected because of this constant shifting and flexibility. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/public-leaders-network/2014/jan/03/sweden-healthcare-coordinate-oecd|title=Swedish healthcare is the best in the world, but there are still lessons to learn|last=Svanborg-Sjövall|first=Karin|date=2014-01-03|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The primary care issues stems from councils. The government has tried to make primary private care more accessible to citizens but the city councils halt this in most counties. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/dec/18/private-healthcare-lessons-from-sweden|title=Private healthcare: the lessons from Sweden|last=Ramesh|first=Randeep|date=2012-12-18|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>The lack of privatized health services leads to a number of the inefficiencies in the system.
== Funding and costs == According to OECD the Swedish health system is one of the best in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/health/sweden-has-excellent-health-care-but-must-improve-care-co-ordination.htm|title=Sweden has excellent health care but must improve care co-ordination, says OECD - OECD|website=www.oecd.org|access-date=2017-12-08}}</ref> The Funding and cost of keeps healthcare affordable and accessible to all Swedish citizens.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anell|first=Anders|date=February 2008|title=The Swedish Healthcare System|url=http://www.pnhp.org/PDF_files/LSE_Country_Profiles.pdf|journal=The Commonwealth Fund|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The funding for Swedish health care comes from central and local taxes. The mandated councils and municipalities have the ability to levy taxes on citizens. Local taxes equate for about 70% of the budgets for councils and municipalities, while overall 85% of the total health budget come from public funding. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://khssocialstudies.weebly.com/uploads/4/4/7/6/4476810/swedish_socialism.pdf|title=Swedish Socialism|last=Rodriguez|first=Linda|date=2009|work=Spinning the Globe: Sweden|access-date=2017-12-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The Swedish government takes about half of the workers' paychecks but single payer healthcare and higher pensions than most countries make this cost viable for each citizen. Costs of Swedish health services are affordable and councils are required by the law to set budgets. Doctors and staff members are placed on salary instead of fluctuating financial incentives that doctors and staff in other countries are allowed. The budgeting manages cost control for health needs and eliminates welfare for private firms or employess who provide service within the public sector.

[[Category:Health in Sweden]]

{{news release |date=April 2012}} {{Infobox organization | name = TeenScreen National Center | bgcolor = <!-- header background color --> | fgcolor = <!-- header text color --> | image = TeenScreen-225px.jpg | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | formation = 1999 | type = <!-- [[Governmental organization|GO]], [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]], [[Intergovernmental organization|IGO]], [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]], etc --> | purpose = Mental health screening | headquarters = [[New York City]] | location = | region_served = | membership = | language = <!-- official languages --> | key_people = Executive director, Laurie Flynn | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at [[Columbia University]] | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = | remarks = | former name = }} The '''TeenScreen National Center for Mental Health Checkups at Columbia University''' was a national [[mental health]] and [[suicide]] risk screening initiative for middle- and high-school age adolescents. On November 15, 2012, according to its website, the program was terminated. The organization operated as a center in the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Department at [[Columbia University]], in [[New York City]]. The program was developed at Columbia University in 1999, and launched nationally in 2003. Screening was voluntary and offered through doctors' offices, schools, clinics, juvenile justice facilities, and other youth-serving organizations and settings. {{As of|2011|08}}, the program had more than 2,000 active screening sites across 46 states in the [[United States]], and in other countries including [[Australia]], [[Brazil]], [[India]] and [[New Zealand]].
==Screening program== ===Organization=== The program was developed by a team of researchers at [[Columbia University]], led by [[David Shaffer]].<ref name=Kaplan>{{cite news |title=Battling a National Killer: TeenScreen Aims To Prevent Teen Suicide |first=Arline |last=Kaplan |url= |newspaper=Psychiatric Times |date=1 March 2006 |page=1}}</ref> The goal was to make researched and validated screening questionnaires available for voluntary identification of possible mental disorders and suicide risk in middle and high school students.<ref name=Vanderwerf>{{cite news |title=County studying two new mental health initiatives |first=Linda |last=Vanderwerf |url= |newspaper=West Central Tribune |date=7 July 2011}}</ref> The questionnaire they developed is known as the Columbia Suicide Screen, which entered into use in 1999, an early version of what is now the Columbia Health Screen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrepp.samhsa.gov/ViewIntervention.aspx?id=150 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002222220/http://www.nrepp.samhsa.gov/ViewIntervention.aspx?id=150 |archivedate=2011-10-02 |df= }}</ref> In 2003, the [[New Freedom Commission on Mental Health]], created under the administration of [[George W. Bush]], identified the TeenScreen program as a "model" program<ref name=Kaplan/> and recommended adolescent mental health screening become common practice.<ref name=New>[[New Freedom Commission on Mental Health]], ''Achieving the Promise: Transforming Mental Health Care in America.'' Final Report. DHHS Pub. No. SMA-03-3832. Rockville, MD: 2003.</ref>
The organization launched an initiative to provide voluntary mental health screening to all U.S. teens in 2003. The following year, TeenScreen was included in the national Suicide Prevention Resource Center's (SPRC) list of [[Evidence-based medicine|evidence-based]] suicide prevention programs.<ref name=Overview04>{{cite web |url=http://www.teenscreen.org/images/stories/PDF/2004%20Annual%20Overview.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425021001/http://www.teenscreen.org/images/stories/PDF/2004%20Annual%20Overview.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 April 2012 |title=Columbia University TeenScreen Program: Science into Policy, Prevention and Action 2004 Overview |year=2004 |work=TeenScreen.org |publisher=Columbia University |accessdate=16 August 2011 }}</ref> In 2007, it was included as an evidence-based program in the U.S. [[Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration]] (SAMHSA)'s National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices.<ref name=NREPP>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrepp.samhsa.gov/ViewIntervention.aspx?id=150 |title=TeenScreen |date=February 2007 |work=National Registry of Evidence-Based Programs and Practice |publisher= |accessdate=10 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002222220/http://www.nrepp.samhsa.gov/ViewIntervention.aspx?id=150 |archivedate=2 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> In 2009, the organization launched the TeenScreen Primary Care initiative to increase mental health screening by pediatricians and other primary care providers, the same year the [[United States Preventive Services Task Force|U.S. Preventive Services Task Force]] recommended annual adolescent mental health screening as part of routine primary care, and the [[Institute of Medicine]] recommended expansion of prevention and early identification programs.<ref name=TIP>{{cite news |title=Will students take a mental health test? |first=Laura |last=Landro |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111904199404576538292146976766 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=30 August 2011 |accessdate=6 September 2011}}</ref>
{{As of |2011}}, the program was led by executive director Laurie Flynn, deputy executive director Leslie McGuire and scientific advisor Mark Olfson, M.D., alongside a National Advisory Council of healthcare professionals, educators and advocates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teenscreen.org/about/our-leadership/ |title=Our Leadership |work=TeenScreen.org |accessdate=16 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524033317/http://www.teenscreen.org/about/our-leadership/ |archivedate=May 24, 2011 }}</ref>
As of November 15, 2012, TeenScreen has been terminated, will no longer train or register new programs, and will cease all operations by the end of the year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teenscreen.org/depression-screening/importance-announcement-regarding-the/ |work=TeenScreen.org |title=Important Announcement for Schools & Communities |accessdate=8 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130416004729/http://www.teenscreen.org/depression-screening/importance-announcement-regarding-the/ |archivedate=16 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===Mission and locations=== The mission of the TeenScreen National Center was to expand and improve the early identification of mental health problems in youth.<ref name="NREPP" /><ref name=Brochure/> In particular, TeenScreen aimed to find young people at risk of suicide or developing mental health disorders so they could be referred for a comprehensive mental health evaluation by a health professional.<ref name=Vanderwerf/> The program focuses on providing screening to young people in the 11-18 age range.<ref name=Brochure>{{cite web |url=http://www.teenscreen.org/images/stories/PDF/NatCenterBrochure3.11.11.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425021210/http://www.teenscreen.org/images/stories/PDF/NatCenterBrochure3.11.11.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 April 2012 |title=TeenScreen National Center Brochure |date=11 March 2011 |work=TeenScreen.org |publisher=TeenScreen National Center |format=PDF |accessdate=6 September 2011 }}</ref> From 2003 until 2012, the program was offered nationally<ref name=Overview04/> in schools, clinics, doctors' offices and in youth service environments such as shelters and juvenile justice settings.<ref name="NREPP"/> {{As of |2011|08}}, more than 2,000 primary care providers, schools and community-based sites in 46 states offered adolescent mental health screening through the TeenScreen National Center. In addition, the screening was also being provided in other countries including [[Australia]], [[Brazil]], [[India]], [[New Zealand]] and [[Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teenscreen.org/programs/local-programs/ |title=Local Programs |work=TeenScreen.org |publisher= |accessdate=16 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130415225409/http://www.teenscreen.org/programs/local-programs/ |archivedate=15 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===Screening process=== TeenScreen provided materials, training and technical help through its TeenScreen Primary Care and Schools and Communities programs for primary care providers, schools and youth-serving organizations that provided mental health screening to adolescents.<ref name=Nursing/> A toolkit was provided, including researched and validated questionnaires, instructions for administering, scoring and interpreting the screening responses. Primary care program materials included information on primary care referrals for clinical evaluation.<ref name=Nursing/> In the school and community setting, the screening process was voluntary and required active parental consent and participant assent prior to screening sessions.<ref name=Kaplan/>
The validated questionnaires included items about depression, thoughts of suicide and attempts, anxiety, and substance use.<ref name="NREPP"/> The screening questionnaires typically took up to ten minutes for an adolescent to complete.<ref name=Kaplan/> Once the responses to the questionnaire had been reviewed, any adolescent identified as being at possible risk for suicide or other mental health concerns would then assessed by a health or mental health professional. The result of this assessment determined whether the adolescent could be referred for mental health services. If this was the case, parents were involved and provided with help locating the appropriate mental health services.<ref name="NREPP"/>
==Research, endorsements and responses== ===Recommendations and research=== Mental health screening has been endorsed by the former U.S. Surgeon General [[David Satcher]], who launched a "Call to Action" in 1999 encouraging the development and implementation of safe, effective school-based programs offering intervention, help and support to young people with mental health issues.<ref name="Surgeon General">{{cite web |url=http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/library/calltoaction/recommendations.htm |title=The Surgeon General's Call To Action To Prevent Suicide, 1999 |year=1999 |work=U.S. Surgeon General |accessdate=12 August 2011}}</ref> TeenScreen is included as an evidence-based program in the U.S. [[Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration]] (SAMHSA)'s National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices as a scientifically tested and reviewed intervention.<ref name="NREPP" /> In addition, the [[United States Preventive Services Task Force|U.S. Preventive Services Task Force]] recommended in 2009 that mental health screening for teenagers be integrated into routine primary care appointments.<ref name=Nursing>{{cite journal |last1=Allen |first1=Patricia L. |last2=McGuire |first2=Leslie |year=2011 |title=Incorporating mental health checkups into adolescent primary care visits |journal=Pediatric Nursing |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=137–41}}</ref>
Studies have been conducted on the effectiveness and impact of mental health screening for young people. In a 2004 systematic evidence review, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force found that there were no studies that addressed whether screening as part of primary care reduced morbidity and mortality, nor any information of the potential risks of screening.<ref name="Systematic review">{{cite web |url=http://www.ahrq.gov/downloads/pub/prevent/pdfser/suicidser.pdf |title=Screening for Suicide Risk: A Systematic Evidence Review for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force |date=May 2004 |work=AHRQ.gov |publisher= |accessdate=10 August 2011}}</ref> In a later review, published in 2009, the task force found that there was evidence supporting the efficacy of screening tools in identifying teenagers at risk of suicide or mental health disorders.<ref name=Williams>{{cite journal |pmid=20722167 |year=2009 |last1=Williams |first1=SB |last2=O'Connor |first2=E |last3=Eder |first3=M |last4=Whitlock |first4=E}}</ref>
A team of researchers from Columbia University and the [[New York State Psychiatric Institute]] completed a [[Randomized controlled trial|randomized controlled clinical trial]] on the impact of suicide screening on high school students in New York State from 2002-2004.<ref name="Gould">{{cite journal | pmid = 15811983 | doi=10.1001/jama.293.13.1635 | volume=293 | issue=13 | title=Evaluating iatrogenic risk of youth suicide screening programs: a randomized controlled trial |date=April 2005 |vauthors=Gould MS, Marrocco FA, Kleinman M, etal | pages=1635–43 | journal=JAMA}}</ref> The study found that students who were given a questionnaire about suicide were no more likely to report suicidal thoughts after the survey than students in the control group who had not been questioned.<ref name="Gould"/> Neither was there any greater risk for "high risk" students.<ref name="Gould"/> A subsequent study by the researchers, in 2009, found that screening appeared to increase the likelihood that adolescents would receive treatment if they were at risk for mental health disorders or suicide.<ref name=Gould2>{{cite journal |pmid=19858758 |year=2009 |last1=Gould |first1=MS |last2=Marrocco |first2=FA |last3=Hoagwood |first3=K |last4=Kleinman |first4=M |last5=Amakawa |first5=L |last6=Altschuler |first6=E |title=Service use by at-risk youths after school-based suicide screening |volume=48 |issue=12 |pages=1193–201 |doi=10.1097/CHI.0b013e3181bef6d5 |pmc=2891889 |journal=Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry}}</ref>
A study published in 2011, involving 2,500 high school students, examined the value of routine mental health screening in school to identify adolescents at-risk for mental illness, and to connect those adolescents with recommended follow-up care. The research, conducted between 2005 and 2009 at six public high schools in suburban Wisconsin, found that nearly three out of four high school students identified as being at-risk for having a mental health problem were not in treatment at the time of screening. Of those students identified as at-risk, a significant majority (76.3 percent) completed at least one visit with a mental health provider within 90 days of screening. More than half (56.3 percent) received minimally adequate treatment, defined as having three or more visits with a provider, or any number of visits if termination was agreed to by the provider.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=881–91 |doi=10.1016/j.jaac.2011.05.013 |title=Mental Health Screening and Follow-up Care in Public High Schools |year=2011 |last1=Husky |first1=Mathilde M. |last2=Sheridan |first2=Marian |last3=McGuire |first3=Leslie |last4=Olfson |first4=Mark |journal=Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry |volume=50 |issue=9}}</ref>
A separate study published in 2011, found that mental health screening was effective at connecting African-American middle school students from a predominantly low-income area with school-based mental health services.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=21559920 |year=2011 |last1=Husky |first1=MM |last2=Kanter |first2=DA |last3=McGuire |first3=L |last4=Olfson |first4=M |title=Mental Health Screening of African American Adolescents and Facilitated Access to Care |doi=10.1007/s10597-011-9413-x |journal=Community mental health journal |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=71–8}}</ref> Researchers have also found evidence to support the addition of mental health screenings for adolescents while undergoing routine physical examinations.<ref name=Husky>{{cite journal |pmid=20127189 |year=2011 |last1=Husky |first1=MM |last2=Miller |first2=K |last3=McGuire |first3=L |last4=Flynn |first4=L |last5=Olfson |first5=M |title=Mental health screening of adolescents in pediatric practice |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=159–69 |doi=10.1007/s11414-009-9207-x |journal=The journal of behavioral health services & research}}</ref>
===Acceptance and critical responses=== Recommendations endorsing adolescent mental health screening have been issued by the [[Institute of Medicine]] (IOM) and the U.S. Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF).<ref name=TIP/> The [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] recommends assessment of mental health at primary care visits and suggests the use of validating screening instruments. These add to statements and recommendations to screen adolescents for mental illness from the American Medical Association (AMA), the Society for Adolescent Health and Medicine, the American Academy of Family Physicians and the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners.<ref name=Nursing/> TeenScreen has been endorsed by a number of organizations, including the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, and federal and state commissions such as the New Freedom Commission.<ref name=Franck>{{cite news |title=Screenings prompt fears of false labels |first=Matthew |last=Franck |url= |newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |date=13 December 2005 |page=A1}}</ref>
There is opposition to mental health screening programs in general and TeenScreen in particular, from civil liberties, parental rights, and politically conservative groups.<ref name=Dejka>{{cite news |title=Can test save lives? |first=Joe |last=Dejka |url= |newspaper=Omaha World-Herald |date=16 September 2008 |page=1A}}</ref> Much of the opposition is led by groups who claim that the organization is funded by the pharmaceutical industry;<ref name="Franck" /> however, in 2011, an inquiry launched by Senator [[Charles E. Grassley]] into the funding of health advocacy groups by pharmaceutical, medical-device, and insurance companies demonstrated to Senator Grassley's satisfaction that TeenScreen does not receive funding from the pharmaceutical industry. Sen. Grassley sent a letter to TeenScreen and 33 other organizations like the American Cancer Society asking about their financial ties to the pharmaceutical industry. TeenScreen replied saying they did not accept money from medical companies. <ref>{{cite news |title=Senator Prods Medical Non-profits to Disclose More About Industry Contributions |first=Suzanne |last=Perry |url=http://philanthropy.com/blogs/government-and-politics/senator-prods-medical-nonprofits-to-disclose-more-about-industry-contributions/28477 |newspaper=The Chronicle of Philanthropy |date=11 May 2011 |accessdate=13 September 2011}}</ref>
In 2005, TeenScreen was criticized following media coverage of a suit filed a local screening program in Indiana by the parents of a teenager who had taken part in screening. The suit alleged that the screening had taken place without parents' permissions.<ref name=BMJ>{{cite news |title=US teenager’s parents sue school over depression screening test |first=Jeanne |last=Lenzer |url=http://www.bmj.com/content/suppl/2005/09/29/331.7519.714-a.DC1 |newspaper=British Medical Journal |year=2005 |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref> The complaint led to a change in how parental consent was handled by TeenScreen sites. In 2006, the program's policy was amended so that active rather than passive consent was required from parents before screening adolescents in a school setting.<ref name="Franck"/>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=25em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111002222220/http://www.nrepp.samhsa.gov/ViewIntervention.aspx?id=150 National Registry of Evidence Based Programs and Practice]

revision.text:
'''Tumour heterogeneity''' describes the observation that different [[tumour cells]] can show distinct [[Morphology (biology)|morphological]] and [[Phenotype|phenotypic]] profiles, including cellular morphology, gene expression, metabolism, motility, proliferation, and metastatic potential.<ref name="Marusyk2010">{{Cite journal | pmid = 19931353 | year = 2010 | author1 = Marusyk | first1 = A | title = Tumor heterogeneity: Causes and consequences | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Reviews on Cancer | volume = 1805 | issue = 1 | pages = 105–117 | last2 = Polyak | first2 = K | doi = 10.1016/j.bbcan.2009.11.002 | pmc = 2814927 }}</ref> This phenomenon occurs both between tumours (inter-tumour heterogeneity) and within tumours (intra-tumour heterogeneity). A minimal level of intra-tumour heterogeneity is a simple consequence of the imperfection of [[DNA replication]]: whenever a cell (normal or cancerous) divides, a few [[mutation]]s are acquired<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 23539594 | year = 2013 | author1 = Vogelstein | first1 = Bert | title = Cancer Genome Landscapes | journal = Science | volume = 373 | issue = 6127 | pages = 1546–1556 | last2 = Papadopoulos | first2 = N. | last3 = Velculescu | first3 = V.E. | last4 = Zhou | first4 = S. | last5 = Diaz | first5 = L.A. | last6 = Kinzler | first6 = K.W. | doi = 10.1126/science.1235122 | pmc=3749880 | bibcode = 2013Sci...339.1546V }}</ref>—leading to a diverse population of cancer cells.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 6372991 | year = 1984 | author1 = Heppner | first1 = G.A. | title = Tumor Heterogeneity | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 44 | issue = 6 | pages = 2259–2265 }}</ref> The [[Genetic heterogeneity|heterogeneity]] of cancer cells introduces significant challenges in designing effective treatment strategies. However, research into understanding and characterizing heterogeneity can allow for a better understanding of the causes and progression of disease. In turn, this has the potential to guide the creation of more refined treatment strategies that incorporate knowledge of heterogeneity to yield higher efficacy.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 30190408 | year = 2018 | author1 = Reiter | first1 = Johannes G | title = Minimal functional driver gene heterogeneity among untreated metastases | journal = Science | volume = 361 | issue = 6406 | pages = 1033-1037 | last2 = Makohon-Moore | first2 = Alvin P | last3 = Gerold | first3 = Jeffrey M | last4 = Heyde | first4 = Alexander | last5 = Attiyeh | first5 = Marc A | last6 = Kohutek | first6 = Zachary A | last7 = Tokheim | first7 = Collin J | last8 = Brown | first8 = Alexia | last9 = DeBlasio | first9 = Rayne | last10 = Niyazov | first10 = Juliana | last11 = Zucker | first11 = Amanda | last12 = Karchin | first12 = Rachel | last13 = Kinzler | first13 = Kenneth W | last14 = Iacobuzio-Donahue | first14 = Christine A | last15 = Vogelstein | first15 = Bert | last16 = Nowak | first16 = Martin A | doi = 10.1126/science.aat7171 }}</ref>
Tumour heterogeneity has been observed in [[leukemias]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 18723673 | year = 2008 | author1 = Campbell | first1 = P. J. | title = Subclonal phylogenetic structures in cancer revealed by ultra-deep sequencing | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 105 | issue = 35 | pages = 13081–13086 | last2 = Pleasance | first2 = E. D. | last3 = Stephens | first3 = P. J. | last4 = Dicks | first4 = E | last5 = Rance | first5 = R | last6 = Goodhead | first6 = I | last7 = Follows | first7 = G. A. | last8 = Green | first8 = A. R. | last9 = Futreal | first9 = P. A. | last10 = Stratton | first10 = M. R. | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0801523105 | pmc = 2529122 | bibcode = 2008PNAS..10513081C }}</ref> [[breast cancer|breast]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 17349583 | year = 2007 | author1 = Shipitsin | first1 = M | title = Molecular definition of breast tumor heterogeneity | journal = Cancer Cell | volume = 11 | issue = 3 | pages = 259–273 | last2 = Campbell | first2 = L. L. | last3 = Argani | first3 = P | last4 = Weremowicz | first4 = S | last5 = Bloushtain-Qimron | first5 = N | last6 = Yao | first6 = J | last7 = Nikolskaya | first7 = T | last8 = Serebryiskaya | first8 = T | last9 = Beroukhim | first9 = R | last10 = Hu | first10 = M | last11 = Halushka | first11 = M. K. | last12 = Sukumar | first12 = S | last13 = Parker | first13 = L. M. | last14 = Anderson | first14 = K. S. | last15 = Harris | first15 = L. N. | last16 = Garber | first16 = J. E. | last17 = Richardson | first17 = A. L. | last18 = Schnitt | first18 = S. J. | last19 = Nikolsky | first19 = Y | last20 = Gelman | first20 = R. S. | last21 = Polyak | first21 = K | doi = 10.1016/j.ccr.2007.01.013 }}</ref> [[prostate cancer|prostate]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 9426051 | year = 1998 | author1 = MacIntosh | first1 = C. A. | title = Precise microdissection of human prostate cancers reveals genotypic heterogeneity | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 23–28 | last2 = Stower | first2 = M | last3 = Reid | first3 = N | last4 = Maitland | first4 = N. J. }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 16166332 | year = 2005 | author1 = Alvarado | first1 = C | title = Somatic mosaicism and cancer: A micro-genetic examination into the role of the androgen receptor gene in prostate cancer | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 65 | issue = 18 | pages = 8514–8518 | last2 = Beitel | first2 = L. K. | last3 = Sircar | first3 = K | last4 = Aprikian | first4 = A | last5 = Trifiro | first5 = M | last6 = Gottlieb | first6 = B | doi = 10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-05-0399 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 7573356 | year = 1995 | author1 = Konishi | first1 = N | title = Intratumor cellular heterogeneity and alterations in ras oncogene and p53 tumor suppressor gene in human prostate carcinoma | journal = The American Journal of Pathology | volume = 147 | issue = 4 | pages = 1112–1122 | last2 = Hiasa | first2 = Y | last3 = Matsuda | first3 = H | last4 = Tao | first4 = M | last5 = Tsuzuki | first5 = T | last6 = Hayashi | first6 = I | last7 = Kitahori | first7 = Y | last8 = Shiraishi | first8 = T | last9 = Yatani | first9 = R | last10 = Shimazaki | first10 = J | pmc = 1871010 }}</ref> [[colon cancer|colon]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 12351679 | year = 2002 | author1 = González-García | first1 = I | title = Metapopulation dynamics and spatial heterogeneity in cancer | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 99 | issue = 20 | pages = 13085–13089 | last2 = Solé | first2 = R. V. | last3 = Costa | first3 = J | doi = 10.1073/pnas.202139299 | pmc = 130590 | bibcode = 2002PNAS...9913085G }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 10469448 | year = 1999 | author1 = Samowitz | first1 = W. S. | title = Regional reproducibility of microsatellite instability in sporadic colorectal cancer | journal = Genes, Chromosomes and Cancer | volume = 26 | issue = 2 | pages = 106–114 | last2 = Slattery | first2 = M. L. | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1098-2264(199910)26:2<106::AID-GCC2>3.0.CO;2-F }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 8686748 | year = 1996 | author1 = Giaretti | first1 = W | title = Intratumor heterogeneity of K-ras2 mutations in colorectal adenocarcinomas: Association with degree of DNA aneuploidy | journal = The American Journal of Pathology | volume = 149 | issue = 1 | pages = 237–245 | last2 = Monaco | first2 = R | last3 = Pujic | first3 = N | last4 = Rapallo | first4 = A | last5 = Nigro | first5 = S | last6 = Geido | first6 = E | pmc = 1865212 }}</ref> [[Brain cancer|brain]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 6372991 | year = 1984 | author1 = Heppner | first1 = G. H. | title = Tumor heterogeneity | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 44 | issue = 6 | pages = 2259–2265 }}</ref> [[Esophageal cancer|esophagus]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 16565718 | year = 2006 | author1 = Maley | first1 = C. C. | title = Genetic clonal diversity predicts progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma | journal = Nature Genetics | volume = 38 | issue = 4 | pages = 468–473 | last2 = Galipeau | first2 = P. C. | last3 = Finley | first3 = J. C. | last4 = Wongsurawat | first4 = V. J. | last5 = Li | first5 = X | last6 = Sanchez | first6 = C. A. | last7 = Paulson | first7 = T. G. | last8 = Blount | first8 = P. L. | last9 = Risques | first9 = R. A. | last10 = Rabinovitch | first10 = P. S. | last11 = Reid | first11 = B. J. | doi = 10.1038/ng1768 }}</ref> [[Head and neck cancer|head and neck]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 8653682 | year = 1996 | author1 = Califano | first1 = J | title = Genetic progression model for head and neck cancer: Implications for field cancerization | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 56 | issue = 11 | pages = 2488–2492 | last2 = Van Der Riet | first2 = P | last3 = Westra | first3 = W | last4 = Nawroz | first4 = H | last5 = Clayman | first5 = G | last6 = Piantadosi | first6 = S | last7 = Corio | first7 = R | last8 = Lee | first8 = D | last9 = Greenberg | first9 = B | last10 = Koch | first10 = W | last11 = Sidransky | first11 = D }}</ref> [[bladder cancer|bladder]]<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 8529469 | year = 1995 | author1 = Sauter | first1 = G | title = Heterogeneity of chromosome 17 and erbB-2 gene copy number in primary and metastatic bladder cancer | journal = Cytometry | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 40–46 | last2 = Moch | first2 = H | last3 = Gasser | first3 = T. C. | last4 = Mihatsch | first4 = M. J. | last5 = Waldman | first5 = F. M. | doi = 10.1002/cyto.990210109 }}</ref> and [[Gynecologic oncology|gynecological carcinomas]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 10646862 | year = 2000 | author1 = Fujii | first1 = H | title = Frequent genetic heterogeneity in the clonal evolution of gynecological carcinosarcoma and its influence on phenotypic diversity | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 60 | issue = 1 | pages = 114–120 | last2 = Yoshida | first2 = M | last3 = Gong | first3 = Z. X. | last4 = Matsumoto | first4 = T | last5 = Hamano | first5 = Y | last6 = Fukunaga | first6 = M | last7 = Hruban | first7 = R. H. | last8 = Gabrielson | first8 = E | last9 = Shirai | first9 = T
}}</ref> [[liposarcoma]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 19734852 | year = 2009 | author1 = Horvai | first1 = A. E. | title = Similarity in genetic alterations between paired well-differentiated and dedifferentiated components of dedifferentiated liposarcoma | journal = Modern Pathology | volume = 22 | issue = 11 | pages = 1477–1488 | last2 = Devries | first2 = S | last3 = Roy | first3 = R | last4 = O'Donnell | first4 = R. J. | last5 = Waldman | first5 = F | doi = 10.1038/modpathol.2009.119 }}</ref> and [[multiple myeloma]].<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 15495197 | year = 2005 | author1 = Pantou | first1 = D | title = Cytogenetic manifestations of multiple myeloma heterogeneity | journal = Genes, Chromosomes and Cancer | volume = 42 | issue = 1 | pages = 44–57 | last2 = Rizou | first2 = H | last3 = Tsarouha | first3 = H | last4 = Pouli | first4 = A | last5 = Papanastasiou | first5 = K | last6 = Stamatellou | first6 = M | last7 = Trangas | first7 = T | last8 = Pandis | first8 = N | last9 = Bardi | first9 = G
| doi = 10.1002/gcc.20114 }}</ref>
==Models of heterogeneity== There are two models used to explain the heterogeneity of tumour cells. These are the [[cancer stem cell]] model and the [[Somatic evolution in cancer|clonal evolution]] model. The models are not mutually exclusive, and it is believed that they both contribute to heterogeneity in varying amounts across different tumour types.<ref name="Shackleton2009">{{Cite journal | pmid = 19737509 | year = 2009 | author1 = Shackleton | first1 = M | title = Heterogeneity in cancer: Cancer stem cells versus clonal evolution | journal = Cell | volume = 138 | issue = 5 | pages = 822–829 | last2 = Quintana | first2 = E | last3 = Fearon | first3 = E. R. | last4 = Morrison | first4 = S. J. | doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2009.08.017 }}</ref>
[[File:CSC vs stochastic.pdf|thumb|upright=1.5|Ability of cancer cells to form tumours under the cancer stem cell and clonal evolution models of heterogeneity.]]
===Cancer stem cells=== {{main|Cancer stem cell}} The cancer stem cell model asserts that within a population of tumour cells, there is only a small subset of cells that are [[Tumorigenic|tumourigenic]] (able to form tumours). These cells are termed cancer stem cells ('''CSCs'''), and are marked by the ability to both self-renew and differentiate into non-tumourigenic progeny. The CSC model posits that the heterogeneity observed between tumour cells is the result of differences in the stem cells from which they originated. Stem cell variability is often caused by [[Epigenetics|epigenetic]] changes, but can also result from clonal evolution of the CSC population where advantageous genetic [[mutation]]s can accumulate in CSCs and their progeny (see below).<ref name="Shackleton2009" />
Evidence of the cancer stem cell model has been demonstrated in multiple tumour types including [[leukemias]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 7509044 | year = 1994 | author1 = Lapidot | first1 = T | title = A cell initiating human acute myeloid leukaemia after transplantation into SCID mice | journal = Nature | volume = 367 | issue = 6464 | pages = 645–648 | last2 = Sirard | first2 = C | last3 = Vormoor | first3 = J | last4 = Murdoch | first4 = B | last5 = Hoang | first5 = T | last6 = Caceres-Cortes | first6 = J | last7 = Minden | first7 = M | last8 = Paterson | first8 = B | last9 = Caligiuri | first9 = M. A. | last10 = Dick | first10 = J. E. | authorlink10 = John Dick (scientist) | doi = 10.1038/367645a0 | bibcode = 1994Natur.367..645L }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 9516140 | year = 1998 | author1 = Wang | first1 = J. C. | title = High level engraftment of NOD/SCID mice by primitive normal and leukemic hematopoietic cells from patients with chronic myeloid leukemia in chronic phase | journal = Blood | volume = 91 | issue = 7 | pages = 2406–2414 | last2 = Lapidot | first2 = T | last3 = Cashman | first3 = J. D. | last4 = Doedens | first4 = M | last5 = Addy | first5 = L | last6 = Sutherland | first6 = D. R. | last7 = Nayar | first7 = R | last8 = Laraya | first8 = P | last9 = Minden | first9 = M | last10 = Keating | first10 = A | last11 = Eaves | first11 = A. C. | last12 = Eaves | first12 = C. J. | last13 = Dick | first13 = J. E. }}</ref> [[glioblastoma]],<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 15549107 | year = 2004 | author1 = Singh | first1 = S. K. | title = Identification of human brain tumour initiating cells | journal = Nature | volume = 432 | issue = 7015 | pages = 396–401 | last2 = Hawkins | first2 = C | last3 = Clarke | first3 = I. D. | last4 = Squire | first4 = J. A. | last5 = Bayani | first5 = J | last6 = Hide | first6 = T | last7 = Henkelman | first7 = R. M. | last8 = Cusimano | first8 = M. D. | last9 = Dirks | first9 = P. B. | doi = 10.1038/nature03128 | bibcode = 2004Natur.432..396S }}</ref> [[breast cancer]],<ref name="Al-Hajj2003">{{Cite journal | pmid = 12629218 | year = 2003 | author1 = Al-Hajj | first1 = M | title = Prospective identification of tumorigenic breast cancer cells | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 100 | issue = 7 | pages = 3983–3988 | last2 = Wicha | first2 = M. S. | last3 = Benito-Hernandez | first3 = A | last4 = Morrison | first4 = S. J. | last5 = Clarke | first5 = M. F. | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0530291100 | pmc = 153034 | bibcode = 2003PNAS..100.3983A }}</ref> and [[prostate cancer]].<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 18539965 | year = 2008 | author1 = Maitland | first1 = N. J. | title = Prostate cancer stem cells: A new target for therapy | journal = Journal of Clinical Oncology | volume = 26 | issue = 17 | pages = 2862–2870 | last2 = Collins | first2 = A. T. | doi = 10.1200/JCO.2007.15.1472 }}</ref>
However, the existence of CSCs is still under debate. One reason for this is that markers for CSCs have been difficult to reproduce across multiple tumours. Further, methods for determining tumourigenic potential utilize [[Xenotransplantation|xenograft]] models. These methods suffer from inherent limitations such as the need to control immune response in the transplant animal, and the significant difference in environmental conditions from the primary tumour site to the xenograft site (''e.g.'' absence of required exogenous molecules or cofactors).<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 24048065 | year = 2013 | author1 = Meacham | first1 = C. E. | title = Tumour heterogeneity and cancer cell plasticity | journal = Nature | volume = 501 | issue = 7467 | pages = 328–337 | last2 = Morrison | first2 = S. J. | doi = 10.1038/nature12624 | pmc = 4521623 | bibcode = 2013Natur.501..328M }}</ref> This has caused some doubt about the accuracy of CSC results and the conclusions about which cells have tumourigenic potential.
===Clonal evolution=== {{main|Somatic evolution in cancer}} The clonal evolution model was first proposed in 1976 by [[Peter Nowell]].<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 959840 | year = 1976 | author1 = Nowell | first1 = P. C. | title = The clonal evolution of tumor cell populations | journal = Science | volume = 194 | issue = 4260 | pages = 23–28 | doi=10.1126/science.959840 | bibcode = 1976Sci...194...23N }}</ref> In this model, tumours arise from a single mutated cell, accumulating additional mutations as it progresses. These changes give rise to additional subpopulations, and each of these subpopulations has the ability to divide and mutate further. This heterogeneity may give rise to subclones that possess an [[Natural selection|evolutionary advantage]] over the others within the [[Tumor microenvironment|tumour environment]], and these subclones may become dominant in the tumour over time.<ref name="Swanton2012">{{Cite journal | pmid = 23002210 | year = 2012 | author1 = Swanton | first1 = C | title = Intratumor heterogeneity: Evolution through space and time | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 72 | issue = 19 | pages = 4875–4882 | doi = 10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-12-2217 | pmc = 3712191 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Merlo | first1 = L. M. F. | last2 = Pepper | first2 = J. W. | last3 = Reid | first3 = B. J. | last4 = Maley | first4 = C. C. | title = Cancer as an evolutionary and ecological process | doi = 10.1038/nrc2013 | journal = Nature Reviews Cancer | volume = 6 | issue = 12 | pages = 924–935 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17109012 | pmc = }}</ref> When proposed, this model allowed for the understanding of tumour growth, treatment failure, and tumour aggression that occurs during the natural process of tumour formation.<ref name="Swanton2012" />
[[File:Linear vs branched.pdf|thumb|left|upright=1.25|Branched evolution is more likely to contribute to tumour heterogeneity.]]
Evolution of the initial tumour cell may occur by two methods:
====Linear expansion====
Sequentially ordered mutations accumulate in driver genes, [[Tumor suppressor gene|tumour suppressor genes]], and [[DNA repair]] enzymes, resulting in clonal expansion of tumour cells. Linear expansion is less likely to reflect the endpoint of a malignant tumour<ref name="Gerlinger2012">{{Cite journal | pmid = 22397650 | year = 2012 | author1 = Gerlinger | first1 = M | title = Intratumor heterogeneity and branched evolution revealed by multiregion sequencing | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 366 | issue = 10 | pages = 883–892 | last2 = Rowan | first2 = A. J. | last3 = Horswell | first3 = S | last4 = Larkin | first4 = J | last5 = Endesfelder | first5 = D | last6 = Gronroos | first6 = E | last7 = Martinez | first7 = P | last8 = Matthews | first8 = N | last9 = Stewart | first9 = A | last10 = Tarpey | first10 = P | last11 = Varela | first11 = I | last12 = Phillimore | first12 = B | last13 = Begum | first13 = S | last14 = McDonald | first14 = N. Q. | last15 = Butler | first15 = A | last16 = Jones | first16 = D | last17 = Raine | first17 = K | last18 = Latimer | first18 = C | last19 = Santos | first19 = C. R. | last20 = Nohadani | first20 = M | last21 = Eklund | first21 = A. C. | last22 = Spencer-Dene | first22 = B | last23 = Clark | first23 = G | last24 = Pickering | first24 = L | last25 = Stamp | first25 = G | last26 = Gore | first26 = M | last27 = Szallasi | first27 = Z | last28 = Downward | first28 = J | last29 = Futreal | first29 = P. A. | last30 = Swanton | first30 = C | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa1113205 | pmc=4878653 }}</ref> because the accumulation of mutations is stochastic in heterogeneic tumours.
====Branched expansion====
Expansion into multiple subclonal populations occurs through a splitting mechanism.<ref name="Swanton2012" /> This method is more associated with tumour heterogeneity than linear expansion. The acquisition of mutations is random as a result of increased [[Genome instability|genomic instability]] with each successive generation. The long-term mutational accumulation may provide a [[Natural selection|selective advantage]] during certain stages of tumour progression. The [[Tumor microenvironment]] may also contribute to tumour expansion, as it is capable of altering the selective pressures that the tumour cells are exposed to.<ref name="Gerlinger2012" />
==Types and causes of heterogeneity== Multiple types of heterogeneity have been observed between tumour cells, stemming from both genetic and non-genetic variability.<ref name="Marusyk2012">{{Cite journal | pmid = 22513401 | year = 2012 | author1 = Marusyk | first1 = A | title = Intra-tumour heterogeneity: A looking glass for cancer? | journal = Nature Reviews Cancer | volume = 12 | issue = 5 | pages = 323–334 | last2 = Almendro | first2 = V | last3 = Polyak | first3 = K | doi = 10.1038/nrc3261 }}</ref>
===Genetic heterogeneity=== Genetic heterogeneity is a common feature of tumour genomes, and can arise from multiple sources. Some cancers are initiated when exogenous factors introduce mutations, such as ultraviolet radiation (skin cancers) and tobacco (lung cancer). A more common source is genomic instability, which often arises when key regulatory pathways are disrupted in the cells. Some examples include impaired [[DNA repair]] mechanisms which can lead to increased replication errors, and defects in the [[mitosis]] machinery that allow for large-scale gain or loss of entire [[chromosome]]s.<ref name="Burrell2013">{{Cite journal | pmid = 24048066 | year = 2013 | author1 = Burrell | first1 = R. Mutational tumor heterogeneity refers to variations in mutation frequency in different genes and samples and can be explored by [http://archive.broadinstitute.org/cancer/cga/mutsig MutSig]. The etiology of mutational processes can considerably vary between tumor samples from the same or different cancer types and can be manifested in different context-dependent mutational profiles. It can be explored by [http://cancer.sanger.ac.uk/cosmic/signatures COSMIC mutational signatures] or [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/research/mutagene/ MutaGene].
===Other heterogeneity=== Tumour cells can also show heterogeneity between their expression profiles. This is often caused by underlying [[Epigenetics|epigenetic]] changes.<ref name="Marusyk2012" /> Variation in expression signatures have been detected in different regions of tumour samples within an individual. Researchers have shown that convergent mutations affecting [[(Histone-H3)-lysine-36 demethylase|H3K36]] [[methyltransferase]] [[SETD2]] and histone H3K4 [[demethylase]] [[JARID1C|KDM5C]] arose in spatially separated tumour sections. Similarly, [[Mammalian target of rapamycin|MTOR]], a gene encoding a cell regulatory [[kinase]], has shown to be constitutively active, thereby increasing S6 [[phosphorylation]]. This active [[phosphorylation]] may serve as a [[biomarker]] in clear-cell carcinoma.<ref name="Gerlinger2012" />
[[Mechanochemistry|Mechanochemical]] heterogeneity is a hallmark of living [[Eukaryote|eukaryotic]] cells. It has an impact on [[Epigenetics|epigenetic]] [[Regulation of gene expression|gene regulation]]. The heterogeneous dynamic mechanochemical processes regulate interrelationships within the group of cellular surfaces through [[adhesion]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=G.M.Edelman |title=Topobiology |journal=J. Scientific American |date=1989 |issue=260 |pages=76–88 }}</ref> Tumour development and spreading is accompanied by change in heterogeneous [[Chaos theory|chaotic dynamics]] of mechanochemical interaction process in the group cells, including cells within tumour, and is hierarchical for the host of cancer patients.<ref>{{cite journal |author= V.E. Orel |author2= N.N Dzyatkovskaya |author3= M.I. Danko |author4= A.V. Romanov |author5= Y.I. Mel'nik |author6= Y.A. Grinevich |author7= S.V. Martynenko |title= Spatial and mechanoemission chaos of mechanically deformed tumor cells |journal=J. Journal of Mechanics in Medicine and Biology |volume=4 |issue=1 |date=2004 |pages=31–45 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/263909869_SPATIAL_AND_MECHANOEMISSION_CHAOS_OF_MECHANICALLY_DEFORMED_TUMOR_CELLS |doi=10.1142/s0219519404000886}}</ref> It is suggested that the heterogeneity of hypoxia in solid tumors is due to the mechanochemical reactions with oxygen nanobubbles.<ref name=mechanochemical>{{cite journal |author= V.B. Orel |author2= M.A. Zabolotny |author3= V.E. Orel |title= Heterogeneity of hypoxia in solid tumours and mechanochemical reactions with oxygen nanobubbles |journal=J. [[Medical Hypotheses]] |date=2017 |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2017.03.006 |volume=102 |pages=82–86}}</ref> The biological phenomena of mechanochemical heterogeneity maybe used for differential [[Stomach cancer|gastric cancer]] diagnostics against patients with [[inflammation]] of [[gastric mucosa]]<ref>{{cite journal |author= V.E. Orel |author2= A.V. Romanov |author3= N.N. Dzyatkovskaya |author4= Yu.I. Mel’nik |title=The device and algorithm for estimation of the mechanoemisson chaos in blood of patients with gastric cancer |journal=J. Medical Engineering & Physics |volume=24 |issue=5 |date=2002 |pages=365–371 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/11322041_The_device_and_algorithm_for_estimation_of_the_mechanoemisson_chaos_in_blood_of_patients_with_gastric_cancer |doi=10.1016/s1350-4533(02)00022-x}}</ref> and for increasing antimetastatic activity of [[dendritic cell]]s based on [[vaccine]]s when mechanically heterogenized [[microparticle]]s of tumor cells are used for their loading.<ref>{{cite journal |author= N. Khranovskaya |author2= V. Orel |author3= Y. Grinevich |author4= O. Alekseenko |author5= A. Romanov |author6= O. Skachkova |author7= N.Dzyatkovskaya |author8= A. Burlaka, |author9= S.Lukin |title= Mechanical heterogenization of Lewis lung carcinoma cells can improve antimetastatic effect of dendritic cells |journal=J. Journal of Mechanics in Medicine and Biology |volume=3 |issue=12 |date=2012 |pages=22 |doi=10.1142/S0219519411004757}} <!--https://www.researchgate.net/publication/260797562_MECHANICAL_HETEROGENIZATION_OF_LEWIS_LUNG_CARCINOMA_CELLS_CAN_IMPROVE_ANTIMETASTATIC_EFFECT_OF_DENDRITIC_CELLS--></ref> There is also a possible methodical approach based on the simultaneous ultrasound imaging diagnostic techniques and therapy, regarding the mechanochemical effect on nanobubles conglomerates with drugs in the tumour.
===Tumour microenvironment=== Heterogeneity between tumour cells can be further increased due to heterogeneity in the [[Tumor microenvironment|tumour microenvironment]]. Regional differences in the tumour (''e.g.'' availability of oxygen) impose different selective pressures on tumour cells, leading to a wider spectrum of dominant subclones in different spatial regions of the tumour. The influence of microenvironment on clonal dominance is also a likely reason for the heterogeneity between primary and [[Metastasis|metastatic]] tumours seen in many patients, as well as the inter-tumour heterogeneity observed between patients with the same tumour type.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 24048067 | year = 2013 | author1 = Junttila | first1 = M. R. | title = Influence of tumour micro-environment heterogeneity on therapeutic response | journal = Nature | volume = 501 | issue = 7467 | pages = 346–354 | last2 = De Sauvage | first2 = F. J. | doi = 10.1038/nature12626 | bibcode = 2013Natur.501..346J }}</ref>
==Implications and challenges==
===Treatment resistance=== Heterogeneic tumours may exhibit different sensitivities to [[Chemotherapy|cytotoxic drugs]] among different clonal populations. This is attributed to clonal interactions that may inhibit or alter therapeutic efficacy, posing a challenge for successful therapies in heterogeneic tumours (and their heterogeneic metastases).<ref name="Marusyk2010" />
Drug administration in heterogeneic tumours will seldom kill all tumour cells. The initial heterogeneic tumour population may [[population bottleneck|bottleneck]], such that few drug resistant cells (if any) will survive. This allows resistant tumour populations to replicate and grow a new tumour through the branching evolution mechanism (see above). The resulting repopulated tumour is heterogeneic and resistant to the initial drug therapy used. The repopulated tumour may also return in a more aggressive manner.
The administration of [[Chemotherapy|cytotoxic drugs]] often results in initial tumour shrinkage. This represents the destruction of initial non-resistant subclonal populations within a heterogeneic tumour, leaving only resistant clones. These resistant clones now contain a selective advantage and can replicate to repopulate the tumour. Replication will likely occur through branching evolution, contributing to tumour heterogeneity. The repopulated tumour may appear to be more aggressive. This is attributed to the drug-resistant selective advantage of the tumour cells.
[[File:Treatment bottleneck.pdf|thumb|center|upright=2.5|Drug treatment induces a bottleneck effect, where resistant subclones will survive and propagate to re-form a heterogeneous tumour.]]
===Biomarker discovery=== Due to the genetic differences within and between tumours, [[biomarker]]s that may predict treatment response or prognosis may not be widely applicable. However, it has been suggested that the level of heterogeneity can itself be used as a biomarker since more heterogeneous tumours may be more likely to contain treatment-resistant subclones.<ref name="Marusyk2012" /> Further research into developing biomarkers that account for heterogeneity is still in progress.
=== Model systems === Current model systems typically lack the heterogeneity seen in human cancers.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Colorectal Cancer Cell Lines Lack the Molecular Heterogeneity of Clinical Colorectal Tumors|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1533002811700317|journal = Clinical Colorectal Cancer|date = 2010-01-01|volume = 9|issue = 1|doi = 10.3816/ccc.2010.n.005|first = James Todd|last = Auman|first2 = Howard L.|last2 = McLeod|pages=40–47}}</ref> In order to accurately study tumour heterogeneity, we must develop more accurate preclinical models. One such model, the [[Patient derived tumor xenografts|patient derived tumour xenograft]], has shown excellent utility in preserving tumour heterogeneity whilst allowing detailed study of the drivers of clonal fitness.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Maintaining Tumor Heterogeneity in Patient-Derived Tumor Xenografts|url = http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/75/15/2963|journal = Cancer Research|date = 2015-08-01|issn = 0008-5472|pmc = 4539570|pmid = 26180079|pages = 2963–2968|volume = 75|issue = 15|doi = 10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-15-0727|first = John W.|last = Cassidy|first2 = Carlos|last2 = Caldas|first3 = Alejandra|last3 = Bruna}}</ref> However, even this model cannot capture the full complexity of cancer.
==Current strategies== While the problem of identifying, characterizing, and treating tumour heterogeneity is still under active research, some effective strategies have been proposed, including both experimental and computational solutions.
===Experimental=== * '''Focused approach:''' analyzing a specific genetic [[Locus (genetics)|locus]] or set of loci. This may occur through the detection of allelic imbalances (tumour DNA is compared to germline DNA), amplification of chromosomal regions ([[Fluorescence in situ hybridization|FISH]]), and/or sequencing specific genes. This method is used to trace the evolution of a specific mutation of interest, or to confirm a mutation researchers may suspect in a tumour.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> ** Advantage: Allows for the analysis of specific genes (''i.e.'' driver genes, tumour suppressors). The process is simple with straightforward interpretation of the results. [[Fluorescence in situ hybridization|FISH]] and [[immunofluorescence]] allows focus on tumour cell subtypes.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> ** Disadvantage: Limited analysis will miss additional important mutations and patterns of clonal expansion. Allelic imbalances may be difficult to verify using microsatellite markers, therefore requiring verification by an independent technique (''i.e.'' FISH). [[Fluorescence in situ hybridization|FISH]] requires large number of cells and is labour-intensive.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> * '''Genome-wide approach:''' analyzing the entire genome in tumour samples. This may be done through [[Karyotype|karyotyping]] or [[Comparative genomic hybridization| comparative genomic hybridization (CGH)]] to detect chromosomal abnormalities. Sequencing of tumour biopsies is becoming more common.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> ** Advantage: Does not rely on prior knowledge to identify variants. [[Karyotype|karyotyping]] identifies regions of large chromosomal abnormalities. [[Comparative genomic hybridization|CGH]] provides unbiased coverage and allows for small-scale allelic imbalances to be detected [[SNP array|(SNP arrays)]]. Sequencing will identify any variants that contribute to tumour heterogeneity.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> ** Disadvantage: Difficult to determine the functional impact of variants (''i.e.'' neutral or pathogenic). Limited resolution. [[Karyotype|Karyotyping]] of cultured cells may be biased towards preferential outgrowth of select tumour cell subpopulations. Limited resolution in both methods.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> The whole-genome approach may generate large amounts of data and be difficult to interpret. * '''Multiregion sampling strategy:''' generally requires multiple post-surgical tumour samples from separate regions of a microdissected tumour. It is important to avoid contamination of non-malignant cells to ensure an accurate representation of gene expression and genetic composition seen within the tumour cells only. Analysis of tumour DNA within the spatially separated regions allows for the construction of a 3-dimensional evolutionary model of tumour heterogeneity.<ref name="Marusyk2010" /> Multiregional sampling is often used in combination with the genome-wide approach to establish this 3D heterogeneity expansion model. * '''Longitudinal sampling:''' through tumour progression or treatment progression, obtaining tumour samples during multiple points in time has been utilized in some cases. This has been suggested as a reliable method for tracking clonal evolution.<ref name="Ding2012" /><ref>{{Cite journal | vauthors= Bai H, Harmancı AS, Erson-Omay AZ, Li J, Coșkun S, Simon M, Krischek B, Özduman K, Omay SB | display-authors = 6 | url = http://www.nature.com/ng/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/ng.3457.html|title = Integrated genomic characterization of IDH1-mutant glioma malignant progression | date = Nov 2015 | journal = Nature Genetics | doi = 10.1038/ng.3457 | pmid=26618343 | pmc=4829945 | volume=48 | issue = 1 | pages=59–66}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 24048068 | year = 2013 | author1 = Bedard | first1 = P. L. | title = Tumour heterogeneity in the clinic | journal = Nature | volume = 501 | issue = 7467 | pages = 355–364 | last2 = Hansen | first2 = A. R. | last3 = Ratain | first3 = M. J. | last4 = Siu | first4 = L. L. | doi = 10.1038/nature12627 | pmc = 5224525 | bibcode = 2013Natur.501..355B }}</ref> However, this technique proves challenging in practice because it requires periodic invasive biopsy. New research into utilizing circulating cell-free tumour DNA in blood may provide a non-invasive way to identify biomarkers throughout treatment.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 23484797 | year = 2013 | author1 = Dawson | first1 = S. J. | title = Analysis of circulating tumor DNA to monitor metastatic breast cancer | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 368 | issue = 13 | pages = 1199–1209 | last2 = Tsui | first2 = D. W. | last3 = Murtaza | first3 = M | last4 = Biggs | first4 = H | last5 = Rueda | first5 = O. M. | last6 = Chin | first6 = S. F. | last7 = Dunning | first7 = M. J. | last8 = Gale | first8 = D | last9 = Forshew | first9 = T | last10 = Mahler-Araujo | first10 = B | last11 = Rajan | first11 = S | last12 = Humphray | first12 = S | last13 = Becq | first13 = J | last14 = Halsall | first14 = D | last15 = Wallis | first15 = M | last16 = Bentley | first16 = D | last17 = Caldas | first17 = C | last18 = Rosenfeld | first18 = N | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa1213261 }}</ref> Longitudinal sampling used in combination with the genome-wide approach will allow for the identification of the accumulated tumour cell mutations through time. This may in turn identify the key driver mutations (seen in initial tumour samples).
* '''Adaptive therapy''' may be used to prevent further tumour growth by adjusting drug dose and timing of drug administration based on the tumour's response. This strategy is assumed to prevent resistant variants from dominating a tumour. However, more research is required into its applicability.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 19487300 | year = 2009 | author1 = Gatenby | first1 = R. A. | title = Adaptive therapy | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 69 | issue = 11 | pages = 4894–4903 | last2 = Silva | first2 = A. S. | last3 = Gillies | first3 = R. J. | last4 = Frieden | first4 = B. R. | doi = 10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-08-3658 | pmc = 3728826 }}</ref>
===Sequencing=== * '''Bulk tumour sequencing''' can be utilized, where DNA is extracted from a mixture of tumour cells and analyzed all at once. The presence of heterogeneous tumour populations (subclones) introduces additional challenges such as: ** The inability to detect [[mutation]]s in rare subclones. Since these mutations will occur with low frequency in the pooled sample, they may be indistinguishable from background noise. However, many variant callers are being actively developed that are specifically designed for cancer data and aim to identify rare variants present in smaller subclonal populations.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 23396013 | year = 2013 | author1 = Cibulskis | first1 = K | title = Sensitive detection of somatic point mutations in impure and heterogeneous cancer samples | journal = Nature Biotechnology | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 213–219 | last2 = Lawrence | first2 = M. S. | last3 = Carter | first3 = S. Since the data is pooled, it is not clear which mutations co-occur and which populations they originate from. New tools are being developed that attempt to resolve clonal structure using [[Allele frequency|allele frequencies]] for the observed mutations.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 22495314 | year = 2012 | author1 = Shah | first1 = S. P. | title = The clonal and mutational evolution spectrum of primary triple-negative breast cancers | journal = Nature | volume = 486 | issue = 7403 | pages = 395–399 | last2 = Roth | first2 = A | last3 = Goya | first3 = R | last4 = Oloumi | first4 = A | last5 = Ha | first5 = G | last6 = Zhao | first6 = Y | last7 = Turashvili | first7 = G | last8 = Ding | first8 = J | last9 = Tse | first9 = K | last10 = Haffari | first10 = G | last11 = Bashashati | first11 = A | last12 = Prentice | first12 = L. M. | last13 = Khattra | first13 = J | last14 = Burleigh | first14 = A | last15 = Yap | first15 = D | last16 = Bernard | first16 = V | last17 = McPherson | first17 = A | last18 = Shumansky | first18 = K | last19 = Crisan | first19 = A | last20 = Giuliany | first20 = R | last21 = Heravi-Moussavi | first21 = A | last22 = Rosner | first22 = J | last23 = Lai | first23 = D | last24 = Birol | first24 = I | last25 = Varhol | first25 = R | last26 = Tam | first26 = A | last27 = Dhalla | first27 = N | last28 = Zeng | first28 = T | last29 = Ma | first29 = K | last30 = Chan | first30 = S. K. | doi = 10.1038/nature10933 | pmc = 3863681 | bibcode = 2012Natur.486..395S }}</ref> * '''[[Single cell sequencing|Single-cell sequencing]]''' is a new technique that is valuable for assessing tumour heterogeneity because it can characterize individual tumour cells. This means that the entire mutational profile of multiple distinct cells can be determined with no ambiguity. While with current technology, it is difficult to evaluate sufficiently large numbers of single cells to obtain statistical power, single-cell tumour data has multiple advantages, including: ** The ability to construct a [[phylogenetic tree]] showing the evolution of tumour populations. Using whole-genome sequences or [[Single-nucleotide polymorphism|SNP]]-based pseudo-sequences from individual cells, the evolution of the subclones can be estimated. This allows for the identification of populations that have persisted over time, and can narrow down the list of mutations that potentially confer a growth advantage or treatment resistance on specific subclones.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 21399628 | year = 2011 | author1 = Navin | first1 = N | title = Tumour evolution inferred by single-cell sequencing | journal = Nature | volume = 472 | issue = 7341 | pages = 90–94 | last2 = Kendall | first2 = J | last3 = Troge | first3 = J | last4 = Andrews | first4 = P | last5 = Rodgers | first5 = L | last6 = McIndoo | first6 = J | last7 = Cook | first7 = K | last8 = Stepansky | first8 = A | last9 = Levy | first9 = D | last10 = Esposito | first10 = D | last11 = Muthuswamy | first11 = L | last12 = Krasnitz | first12 = A | last13 = McCombie | first13 = W. R. | last14 = Hicks | first14 = J | last15 = Wigler | first15 = M | doi = 10.1038/nature09807 | pmc = 4504184 | bibcode = 2011Natur.472...90N }}</ref> Algorithms for inferring a tumor phylogeny from single-cell DNA sequencing data include SCITE,<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Jahn|first1=Katharina|title=Tree inference for single-cell data|journal=Genome Biology|volume=17|date=2016|doi=10.1186/s13059-016-0936-x}}</ref> OncoNEM <ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Ross|first1=Edith|title=OncoNEM: inferring tumor evolution from single-cell sequencing data|journal=Genome Biology|volume=17|date=2016|doi=10.1186/s13059-016-0929-9|url=https://genomebiology.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13059-016-0929-9}}</ref> and SiFit.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Zafar|first1=Hamim|title=SiFit: inferring tumor trees from single-cell sequencing data under finite-sites models|journal=Genome Biology|volume=18|date=2017|doi=10.1186/s13059-017-1311-2}}</ref> * '''Section sequencing''' can be done on multiple portions of a single solid tumour, and the variation in the mutation frequencies across the sections can be analyzed to infer the clonal structure. The advantages of this approach over single sequencing include more statistical power, and availability of more accurate information on the spatial positioning of samples. The latter can be used to infer the frequency of clones in sections and provide insight on how a tumour evolves in space. To infer the clones genotypes and phylogenetic trees that model a tumour evolution in time, several computational methods were developed<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kuipers|first1=Jack|title=Advances in understanding tumour evolution through single-cell sequencing|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Reviews on Cancer|volume=1867|issue=2|pages=127|date=2017|doi=10.1016/j.bbcan.2017.02.001}}</ref><ref name="rev2017">{{cite journal|last1=Schwartz|first1=Russell|title=The evolution of tumour phylogenetics: principles and practice|journal=Nature Reviews Genetics|date=13 Feb 2017|doi=10.1038/nrg.2016.170|pmid=28190876|volume=18|issue=4|pages=213–229}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Farahani|first1=Hossein|last2=de Souza|first2=Camila P. Shah|first10=Sohrab|title=Engineered in-vitro cell line mixtures and robust evaluation of computational methods for clonal decomposition and longitudinal dynamics in cancer|journal=Scientific Reports|date=18 October 2017|volume=7|issue=1|doi=10.1038/s41598-017-13338-8|bibcode=2017NatSR...713467F}}}</ref> including Clomial,<ref name=Clomial>{{cite journal|last1=Zare|first1=Habil|title=Inferring clonal composition from multiple sections of a breast cancer|journal=PLOS Computational Biology|date=2014|volume=10|issue=7|pages=e1003703|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003703|pmid=25010360|pmc=4091710|bibcode=2014PLSCB..10E3703Z}}</ref> cloneHD,<ref name=cloneHD>{{cite journal|last1=Fischer|first1=Andrej|title=High-definition reconstruction of clonal composition in cancer|journal=Cell Reports|date=2014|volume=7|issue=5|pages=1740–1752|doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2014.04.055|pmid=24882004|pmc=4062932}}</ref> PhyloWGS,<ref name=PhyloWGS>{{cite structure in cancer|journal=Nature Methods|date=2014|pages=396–398|doi=10.1038/nmeth.2883|volume=11|issue=4|pmid=24633410|pmc=4864026}}</ref> Cloe,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Marass|first1=Francesco|title=A phylogenetic latent feature model for clonal deconvolution|date=2015|arxiv=1604.01715|doi=10.1214/16-AOAS986|volume=10|issue=4|journal=The Annals of {{more footnotes|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Wanda Rutkiewicz | image = Wanda Rutkiewicz, Góry Sokole, fot. Seweryn Bidziński.jpg | alt = | caption = Wanda Rutkiewicz climbing on [[Góry Sokole]] (Falcon Mountains) in 1968 | birth_date = {{birth date|1943|2|4}} | birth_place = [[Plungė]], [[Lithuania]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1992|5|13|1943|2|4}} | death_place = [[Kangchenjunga]], [[Nepal]] | nationality = [[Poles|Polish]] | other_names = | known_for = First woman to successfully climb [[K2]] | occupation = [[Mountaineer]] }} '''Wanda Rutkiewicz''' {{IPA-pl|/ˈvanda rutˈkievitʂ/}} (February 4, 1943 – May 12–13, 1992) was a [[Poland|Polish]] computer engineer<ref name=martina>{{cite web|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17430437.2016.1175139?src=recsys&journalCode=fcss20 |title=Wanda Rutkiewicz – crossing boundaries in women’s mountaineering |author=Martina Gugglberger |date=24 April 2016}}</ref> and mountain climber. She was the first woman to successfully summit [[K2]].
==Early life== Wanda Rutkiewicz was born in a Polish family in [[Plungė]], Lithuania. After World War II, her family chose [[Repatriation of Poles (1944–1946)|to leave for Poland]], settling in [[Wrocław]] in southwestern Poland's [[Recovered Territories]], where she graduated from [[Wroclaw University of Technology]] as an electrical engineer.
She began climbing on the rocks near the [[Janowice Wielkie]] - Falcon Mountains ({{lang-pl|Góry Sokole}}).
Wanda Rutkiewicz rode [[SFM Junak|Junak]], the heaviest Polish motorcycle, which indirectly contributed to her interest in climbing. One summer day in 1961, it ran out of fuel. She started waving to people passing her vehicle. The man riding the motorcycle which stopped to help was travelling with a colleague Bogdan Jankowski, who had been climbing for two years. This meeting resulted in their climbing of the [[:pl:Góry Sokole|Falcon Mountains]].
==Climbing career== Her first major expedition was to the [[Pamir Mountains]] with [[Andrzej Zawada]], which she found unpleasent due to fractured relationships with male climbers.<ref name=cul>{{cite web|url=https://culture.pl/en/article/death-before-failure-wanda-rutkiewicz-the-golden-age-of-polish-mountaineering |title=Death Before Failure: Wanda Rutkiewicz & The Golden Age of Polish Mountaineering |date=23 August 2017 |accessdate=15 June 2018 |author=Michael Keller |publisher=Culture.pl}}</ref>
After returning began to lead her own expeditions, including a number of all female ones, and became known for a blunt leadership style.<ref name=cul/>
On 16 October 1978, she became the third woman, the first Pole, and the first European woman to reach the summit of [[Mount Everest]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Jordan |first=Jennifer |title=Savage Summit: The Life and Death of the First Women on K2 |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2006 |pages=40 |isbn=978-0-06-058716-1}}</ref> In 1986 she became the first woman to successfully climb [[K2]], which she did without supplemental oxygen, as part of a small expedition led by [[Liliane and Maurice Barrard|Lilliane and Maurice Barrard]]. Her triumph was marred when both the Barrards died on the descent, becoming [[1986 K2 disaster|two of thirteen climbers to die on K2 that summer]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Jordan |first=Jennifer |title=Savage Summit: The Life and Death of the First Women on K2 |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2006 |pages=84–94 |isbn=978-0-06-058716-1}}</ref>
[[File:Kamien.pamiatkowy.Wanda.Rutkiewicz.jpg|thumb|A memorial stone at the entrance to the II LO (The Secondary School #2) in [[Wrocław]]]] Rutkiewicz's goal was to become the first woman to summit all fourteen of the [[eight-thousanders]]. During her climbing life she successfully summitted the following mountains: * 1975 - [[Gasherbrum III]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=pl&u=http://natemat.pl/228723,alison-chadwick-druga-zona-onyszkiewicza-ktora-zginela-w-gorach&prev=search |title=Alison Chadwick, the second wife of Onyszkiewicz, who died in the mountains. They met in the Tatra Mountains, together they captured the Himalayas |accessdate=11 June 2018 |publisher= naTemat.pl}}</ref> * 1978 - [[Mount Everest]] * 1985 - [[Nanga Parbat]] * 1986 - [[K2]] * 1987 - [[Shishapangma]] * 1989 - [[Gasherbrum II]] * 1990 - [[Gasherbrum I]] * 1991 - [[Cho Oyu]] * 1991 - [[Annapurna I]] * 1992 - [[Kangchenjunga]] (uncertain)
==Death== While climbing Kangchenjunga, 49-year-old Rutkiewicz was last seen alive by Mexican climber [[Carlos Carsolio]]. She was sheltering at high altitude on the north-west face, during her attempted ascent of what would have been her ninth eight-thousander. At that moment Rutkiewicz was physically weakened and not able to make a rational decision that could have saved her life. Carsolio said that he didn't have the mental strength left to convince her to descend because he was weakened as well.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jordan |first=Jennifer |title=Savage Summit: The Life and Death of the First Women on K2 |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2006 |pages=171–174 |isbn=978-0-06-058716-1}}</ref>
It was thought that the body was found on the south-west face of the mountain in 1995 by [[Fausto de Stefani]], [[Marco Galezzi]] and [[Silvio Mondinelli]], suggesting that she had climbed up the north-west ridge to a point very close to the summit before falling down the south-west side. However, more detailed analysis of the findings by the Italian climbers, such as colour of clothing and presence of Bulgarian-made tablets with the body, indicate that most likely it was the body of Bulgarian climber [[Yordanka Dimitrova]], who was killed by an [[avalanche]] on the south-west face of Kangchenjunga in October 1994. It is not known if Rutkiewicz summitted Kangchenjunga. If she did so, she would have been the first woman to reach the top of the world's three highest mountains. Rutkiewicz's body has still not been found.
==See also== *[[List of 20th-century summiters of Mount Everest]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * Reinisch, Getrude, ''Wanda Rutkiewicz: A Caravan of Dreams'' (2000) {{ISBN|0-9538631-0-7}} * ''Freedom Climbers'' {{ISBN|978-1-926855-60-8}} [http://rmbooks.com/book_details.php?isbn_upc=9781926855608 Freedom Climbers by Bernadette McDonald]
==External links== * [http://www.everesthistory.com/wanda.htm Everest History: Wanda Rutkiewicz] * [http://winterclimb.com/climbing-base/item/29-wanda-rutkiewicz Biography of Wanda Rutkiewicz] *[https://culture.pl/en/podcast/SFTEW-15-Climb CLIMB], podcast from [[Culture.pl]]'s ''Stories From The Eastern West'' about Rutkiewicz.
